title: First Class App for Alexa
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2018
content: I don't understand the reviews complaining about the cost of the service.  While I have no knowledge of how the web site presented information in 2016 and 2017, at the current time, March 2018, the website if very, very clear about cost.  The service is free if you have fewer than 5 contacts and use 10 or fewer notifications in a 30 day period.  For $3.66 a month you can use 120 notifications per month, and for $5 per month you can get 400 notifications per month, have 10 contacts, and use numerous languages other than English.  I signed up for the free service and tested it and it works flawlessly.  Since I opted for voice call and text, each instance uses 2 notifications, and because I am adding one additional contact, each notification will use 4 notifications.  For that reason I am going back into my account and signing up for the $5 per month option.  I am currently paying $32 per month for a medical alert system for my wife, but she fell this morning and wasn't wearing the necklace so it was of no help.  However, she has and Echo Dot on her bedside table, and if I had signed up for Ask My Buddy sooner, she could have just said, "Alexa, alert Bill" and Ask My Buddy would have called my cell phone.  The instructions say that you should say "Alexa, tell Ask My Buddy to alert (contact name)", but I quickly discovered that you only need to say "Alexa, alert (contact name)", and Alexa will respond with "I will tell Ask My Buddy to alert (contact name)".  That may seem lilke and inconsequential difference, but for an elderly person in distress, and possibly with confusion as well, the 3 word command is much surer than the 8 word command.  While I should be able to just say, "Alexa, call (contact)", I have found over the past few months that the Echo Dot response to that is spotty.  Sometimes it works, sometimes Alexa just lights up green and beeps, but never makes the call.  In any case, with that, the person in distress would have to communicate via Alexa which at distance could be difficult.  The Ask My Buddy command will send a prerecorded message that will tell you that the person in distress needs help and you should check on them immediately.  This is as good a use of technology as can be devised and I recommend it without reservation.

title: How to set up Ask My Buddy for a senior
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2019
content: Here is how we setup Ask My Buddy for my 97-year-old father who lives alone:1. Living room has an Echo. Bedroom and bathroom each have an Echo dot.2.  Taped next to each Echo device is a cheat sheet for the Ask My Buddy commands, of which he uses two: call all of us for help and tell all of us he's ok.3.  We schedule drills twice a month on the first and fifteenth of each month.  I verify with Pop the procedure and alert the other contacts in advance of each scheduled test.  He issues both commands during each test.4.  We rotate the tests so that he exercises each of his Echo devices in turn.5.  I frequently call in to his Echo device using the Alexa app on my android phone and the "Drop in" feature.  This lets me listen to his living room without his having to do anything to receive the call.6.  We will soon implement an additional, daily "Check-In" message from Pop to all of us.  Since we talk with him frequently, but not necessarily every day, this step will provide positive confirmation that he is all right at least once a day.These steps are necessary, because unless he rehearses sending messages he might not remember what to say in a real emergency.

title: Fantastic. Highly recommend. Just wish 1 thing...
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2018
content: This skill is exactly as advertised. Absolutely fantastic.I only wish you could adjust a setting so you could just say ‚ÄúAlexa, alert so and so‚Äù rather than having to say ‚ÄúAlexa, tell MyBuddy to alert...‚ÄùCould be hard to remember, especially for elderly/disabled persons, to say MyBuddy. Especially in an emergency situation and so infrequently using the skill.

title: My er was to late  get yours now I now have added my buddy to Alexa !!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2016
content: I had a heart attack n middle of night was alone woke up to hear someone screaming . IT WAS ME!!I couldn't get out of bed nor get to a phone yes I had a heart attack but I lost 2/3 of my heart  ability I wish I had Alexa back thenBut I Do now and trust me don't wait till the er moment and think I should have gotten that Alexa thingNo one has paid me to say this . It comes from my own experience!! Thanks guys for added ing this to Alexa .

title: A Perfect Combination of Technologies offering Freedom of Movement and Peace of Mind
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2016
content: Sometimes technologies can match up so well as to become nearly perfect solutions for some of the most challenging problems we face. Take the task of taking care of our elderly family and friends - Ask My Buddy steps up as one of those perfect solutions. It leverages Alexa's "always on" capabilities so that my blind 89-year-old father has the means to call out if his cell phone battery dies (which happened today), he falls or is otherwise in need of help at a time no one is around. This combination skill and service along with the voice-interface that Alexa provides gives my father freedom of movement and all of his family a greater sense of security.In fact, I think this company should be bought out by Amazon and incorporated into all Echo units by default since it offers such a vital service for anyone, not only the elderly, to send a quick message for help. It also isn't bad for Dot sales in that we are now buying 3 more Echo dots for various remote areas of the house to accommodate this skill's capabilites. Ask My Buddy rocks!

title: Thanks,  thanks
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2019
content: I'm a  mature Nurse who lives alone.  Don't let the gray hair fool you,  i still work full time. One night I got very ill and knew I needed help,  with one big breath i asked Alexa to call  my Buddy, before  i hit the floor. She did and they came running calling the ambulance. All is well i just want to say Thanks .

title: IT DOES NOT GET ANY BETTER!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2016
content: My wife has MS and has fallen many times, only to be stuck for hours until someone came home. Echo is now her guardian as well as companion....Thank you so much. Who would of thought this was possible.

title: Perfect piece of mind for parents of new ‚Äúlatch-key‚Äù kid this school year!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2020
content: My daughter just started middle school this school year and now walks home from school.  We know our child very well and she is not responsible enough to have a standard cellphone.  We bought a tik-talk watch that allows her to call only the contacts we program in it, call 911 in an emergency, receive calls from anyone; that‚Äôs a bummer (and not okay for us) but understands it‚Äôs the same lesson about ‚Äúdon‚Äôt answer the door to anyone that‚Äôs not mom or dad!‚Äù She can send texts to the contancts in her list, too, and it‚Äôs trackable even inside a building!!What makes this app/skill perfect is, when she gets home, locks the door, and sets the house alarm she tells Alexa to have My buddy send everyone a ‚Äúcheck-in‚Äù and my husband and I are notified via 3 means of communication (text message, email and phone call) that she‚Äôs made it home.  We know for a fact that if she had just a cell phone she would not develop this routine and forget to call us, we would be engrossed in our jobs at the time she gets home from school and be completely unaware that she didn‚Äôt check-in giving a potential problem a headstart on the clock.  Now I am not saying the skill will save my childs life!  But this skill provides our family some piece of mind, and because of the routine notifications it has helped us to recognize our patterned behaviors and know when we‚Äôre doing a specific thing/task during the day is when to expect her notification; again adding that piece of mind!One thing I would change about this skill is the notification system.  I wish it would allow you to choose your preference(s) of notification between text message, email, or phone call or and of those as a combination.  My preference would be to have both the text message and phone call but I don‚Äôt need or want the email notifications.

title: Alert First Responders By Voice
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2021
content: I am primarily using AskMyBuddy as an inexpensive Medical Alert system.AskMyBuddy can contact either the Fire or Police departments, however I would, typically, use 911.PROSVery low monthly cost.Voice activated. No need to wear a pendant. (Seniors HATE that pendant.)CONSRequires Amazon Echo smart speaker devices throughout your dwelling. (I have four to cover my 2400 square foot condo.)Very difficult for a senior to set up without help, because it requires AskMyBuddy, Buddy Assist, your smartphone, Alexa, Noonlight, and a lockbox. (Your traditional Medical Alert services are, essentially, turnkey.)The AskMyBuddy commands are too wordy, and could be hard to remember under stress. (This can be solved using an Alexa Routine with a Custom command, e.g. Alexa, Call medical, or Alexa, Help!)I'm eighty years old, but I was a computer guy in my previous life. It was a struggle, but I had fun setting this up. All the pieces are available, but the AskMyBuddy folks need to do some fine tuning.

title: My Mom Fell
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2017
content: My mom fell last week and was unable to get up. She alerted family via Ask My Buddy and we were then able to summon EMS. Awesome App

title: Alert your Alerts!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2016
content: Getting signed in and adding contacts was very simple. Just make sure you've gotten a hold of everyone before testing the alert! I thought I texted all my contacts before testing the alert message and missed one. Scared her half to death. After assuring her I was fine we had a good laugh. So, heads up people!

title: An amazing free service
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2017
content: I haven't had to use this in an emergency, but I have run a couple tests and the system has worked as hoped. Set up was incredibly easy.While it isn't a factor on the Alexa app, I have to say that the development team is excellent. After setting up on my Echo Dot I contacted the development team about using it on my PC and they were right there explaining what I had missed in the set up. They have followed up twice with me checking if I have questions on either device. You don't usually get service this good for paid apps!I have two conditions that make me prone to falls, but neither one is severe enough for my insurer to pay for a traditional emergency button. Although Ask My Buddy isn't the same as a  911 service, it does take some of the fear away from my being alone. Especially at night when I am tired and most afraid to fall.Finally, if like me, you can't afford the subscription service, consider making a one time donation to the team. It costs them money to run this and, unlike the games we all play daily, there are no in app ads here.

title: Wonderful APP.....Thank You.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content: This is a fantastic addition to Alexa.  I pray that I never need it, but, it is comforting to know that as an older lady of 76 if I should fall in my home I may have a chance of getting help.  Thank you so much.

title: Grateful for Ask My Buddy!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2018
content: Two weeks ago my Mom was rushing to get to the beauty shop and fell inside her condo. She asked Alexa to call me and I was able to arrive there within 10 minutes.  Mom and I are so grateful for Ask My Buddy and our Alexa! She had a fractured pelvis and is now on the road to recovery.

title: Works great and I am lucky I have set this up.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2018
content: This why I first got an Amazon Echo. Ask My Buddy works great and is great peace of mind for someone like me.  I have taken a few falls and was worried about what to do without my phone being available.  I have now used Ask my Buddy with another fall.  My kids all got the message and when they could not reach me on my phone came over to help me.  I think anyone who lives alone should have something like this, no matter what their age.  Oh I forgot, I use the check in feature every morning to let them all know I am up and about.

title: My new buddy
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
content: This is great for those parents or kids that live alone. Highly recommend. And it is free up to 5 contacts.üíóüíóüíó

title: An AMAZING Skill!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2018
content: We needed something to help protect a dear loved one in the event he was unable to call for help - for ANY reason. An independent man, who has always taken care of so many others, was willing try out what I initially thought would be a ‚Äògood thing‚Äô. I wanted something that was discreet, accurate, easy to use, waterproof (showers), and would last. What I bought, although it has great potential, was not a good fit. It alarmed FREQUENTLY, for no reason. If he heard the alarm ‚Äòvoice message‚Äô, he could cancel the alert, but more times than not, it sent out alerts and I would contact him to verify he was okay as much as 10 times in a single day! It wasn‚Äôt for him. While searching for a more workable solution, I came across Ask My Buddy and thought this could be the ONE! I bought 4 AMAZON Echo/Alexa Dots and shared this skill. He had all the Dots by Thanksgiving; set up 1 Dot just to appease me (read that as...shut me up!). I e-mailed him a lengthy list of all the stuff/skills I use my Alexa for, and he did start with a shopping list. The next morning, he CALLED me via his DOT! He read all the stuff I‚Äôd sent, and hooked everything up Thanksgiving night! We enabled the Ask My Buddy skill, tested it out, and it worked beautifully! I can honestly say, I was reduced to tears! So thankful! The Dots were placed strategically around the house; upstairs, downstairs, just outside the bathroom, and the garage - all able to hear from 2 locations - and we are all very pleased. The second best part of my story/review? I learned yesterday that he bought 3 more Dots to give to his sisters...and shared the Ask My Buddy skill! ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Works Perfectly
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2019
content: I just finished setting this up for myself as I live alone. All of my contacts got notified immediately and let me know so we‚Äôre all set. I fell and broke my knee a few months ago so I‚Äôve been finding this very exciting to have as it will alert everyone all at once.I was trying to reach one daughter before and she was not available so this gives me back up.

title: It really works!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2016
content: I have mine set up for my mom who lives w me, so when I'm away from home she can activate if necessary. Last night, was being demonstrated on tv and highlighting the "ask my buddy" app.  Well my Alexa heard the command and the next thing I know my cell phone rings and text message is sent telling me to check on my mom! Of course I knew she was fine sitting across the room from me. The kicker was that my husband out of town also called in not knowing it was a "test/mistake" and wanted to make sure everything was ok. Brilliant!!

title: My mom isn't good with electronics and smartphones but this is very easy
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2017
content: It really works! My mom lives in Hawaii and we're on  the mainland. It works and gives us a sense of peace. My mom isn't good with electronics and smartphones but this is very easy. Highly recommend. Thanks for making this available!

title: Too Hard  to Remember
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2017
content: I am a senior...when my husband passed out I couldn`t think to say "ask my buddy to call-----"it would be easier to say Alexa, call 911 or call Rob....under stress this was too hard for me....by the time I called someone my husband almost died

title: Oops
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2017
content: If you have added 'ask my buddy' beware if you have HSN/QVC on the TV & they are demonstrating this. App.I was getting ready for bed one evening when they were demonstrating Echo.  They said Alexa, ask my buddy.  Well, my Alexa woke up & contacted my contacts.  One of my buddies was the speech writer for a large event & in then middle she got the text.  So, I caution you üòù.  It works extremely well

title: Was needed within 2-weeks
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2017
content: I haven't had to use 'Ask My Buddy' for myself but, I have peace of mind knowing it's there.  I did sign up my parents for this service and 2-weeks later my mom fell down the stairs and injured her hip.  She did not have her cell phone on her and was too far away from the house phones to reach them.  It took about 10-minutes (to get over her initial panic) but, then she remembered 'Ask My Buddy' and called out for help.  I got to her within 30-minutes and was able to call an ambulance.  I am so glad this service is available.

title: Home Alone? A must have!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2020
content: This is so helpful, and a safety must have.You just say:  Alexa, ask my buddy for help. and immediately your designated "buddy" or buddies receive a phone call and a text. When I go food shopping and my husband- who has severe disabilities - falls, or needs me urgently- can simply call out to Alexa, and I am alerted immediately.  This is awesome... and a relief. :)

title: Alexa's version of I've fallen and I can't get up!"
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2016
content: Awesome!! Thank you for creating a way for elderly people to be able to contact their loved ones in the event of an emergency.  This is a great service and I can't recommend it enough.

title: You've put my friends' minds at ease...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2017
content: I am an older disabled widow, living alone, with no way of getting help should I fall or otherwise be unable to get to my phone.  When my best friend showed up a few days ago with an Echo Dot, in hopes that I would be able to use it in an emergency, I immediately began looking for some way to manage this easily.  Last night I found this skill - read many many positive reviews - thought about it overnight - and decided to give it a whirl this morning. I went to the website and signed up first, added my contacts' information, then came back here and enabled the skill and linked it by signing into the site thru the link dialogue above. Then I tested it out with my two friends, and with one small adjustment (Alexa couldn't understand one friend's name, so I went back to the contact page and gave him an easier-to-understand nickname instead) everything worked flawlessly!  It was a very straightforward setup, and now both my friends and myself can breathe a bit easier, knowing that as long as Alexa is working, I can call for help.  Thank you so much, devs!!

title: Great idea, difficult implimentation.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2020
content: I have a rare neuromuscular disease, and sometimes become paralysed.  Ive got echo dots all over the house to help me ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù my environment....lights, temp, locks, even some doors.  I have gone from nearly normal to paralysed in less than 5 minutes....and i need to be medicated immediately. Ive tried to set this up for my wife. During the ‚Äútesting‚Äù phase I‚Äôd say ‚Äúask my buddy for help ‚Äù, and everytime it would suggest i setup the app...which I‚Äôd already done mutiple times. So here is the problem, as I figure.  You have to say ‚Äúask my buddy to help me..and not ‚Äúfor help‚Äù.  Honestly Im not sure I‚Äôd remember that as I ‚Äúgo down the rabbit hole‚Äù.  Customer support was awesome....but for now still carrying the meds around all the time,  using Alexa‚Äôs announce function, boat horns, and carry my phone.

title: Better than free
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2017
content: This is a free service for everyone who has an Amazon Echo. The basic service will let you notify close family/friends in an emergency, and that's all most folks really need. Let the family members and friends you list as emergency contacts know that you've put them down to receive a text or voice call if you have an emergency. (This Echo skill does NOT call 911 directly).Contributing a few bucks a year lets you list more than 5 contacts and is totally optional. Any contribution is a nice way to support an important service, and even if you stop contributing none of your contacts will be de-listed. This Echo app is way cheaper than the emergency alert services that sponsor annoying TV ads for dedicated hardware devices for those living alone.Highly recommended.

title: Great for Seniors
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2018
content: We've all seen that commercial "I've fallen down and can't get up." The challenge with that line of products is it requires people to wear a wrist band or pendant that holds the button triggering the system. As a resident in a 55+ senior community, and qualifying as a senior by age, I've started helping neighbors put the Alexa Dot - Ask My Buddy solution in place where they can use this skill to issue the "ask my buddy to alert" command, contacting neighbors and family when there is an emergency need.

title: I appreciate this was created, however many in need aren't going to remember to say "Ask My Buddy"
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
content: From experience, people in need aren't going to remember or give a crap about saying "Alexa" or "Ask My Buddy" before they state their need.  What they will say with instinct, realizing there is or isn't a device that can hear them, is something to the affect "Help me, Help me.  Oh it hurts, I need help, please help me.  Can anyone help me? Call 911 or do something, please help me."By then, any device, Alexa or otherwise, should have heard at least "help" enough to trigger and ask for further information.  "Do you need me to alert the house, or call 911?"It's a good approach and a good thing for you to start, because this is already necessary and right now.  People in dire need don't think, they just react.

title: Ask My Buddy is pure piece of mind !
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2017
content: Ask My Buddy is pure piece of mind !I have a very active 84 year old Mom and I worry about her falling or somerhing worse, We tested Ask My Buddy from every room in her home which is a 2 bedroom single wide yes that's Alexa listening but I know she will get help anywhere in her home.Mom can alert everyone in our family and a neighbour. If you have an older parent or you are a living breathing human being then Ask My Buddy is for you.Read other reviews it has saved lives !

title: Amazing!! Just try it. You won't be sorry.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2016
content: I have not needed to use this skill yet, and I hope I never will, but it is comforting to know it's there. After setting it up (which was so easy and fast) I tested it. I told everyone on my list it was just a test. It worked just like they said it would. Everyone was notified in seconds and I truly mean seconds! Just having it there put my mind and my family members minds a little more at ease. This skill is absolutely amazing. Even if you think you might need it someday but doubt it, just take the seconds to set it up. You won't be sorry. You just never know if or when you may need it.

title: Peace of mind
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: Having breathing issues this app is a lifesaver when you can't make it to a phone when your short of breathe. Alexa and ask my buddy can have my help notified quickly. Thanks

title: Great Customer Service
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
content: A basic account (allowing for a limited number of alerts per month) is completely free, so it came as a surprise that AskMyBuddy has such great customer service!  I was having trouble linking Alexa to my mother's AskMyBuddy account, so I emailed their support, and they called me right back and talked me through an alternate approach, which worked.  It was the best customer service I've ever received from a free product!  Mom is very comforted knowing she has AskMyBuddy available in case she should fall down in her house; in fact it was the main reason she bought her Echos.

title: ASK MY BUDDY IS GREAT! ALL RESIDENTIAL PEOPLE WITH A COMPUTER SHOULD USE THIS!!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2020
content: I live in a residential care facility and use this whenever i need assistance. This works great and is work every penny! The people who monitor this feature will provide you with assistance if you need it. It is great and I love it to death. It helps me ALL the time.

title: Good App - Could be Great with 1 Improvement
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2017
content: As others have noticed, when calls go out to friends, relatives, etc, the call is identified in caller-id an out of state, unrecognized phone number only. Like most folks these days, I ignore, even block those unknown, always annoying out of state nuisance calls.  Should be able to reflect a recognizable name, like "Ask My Buddy Needs You" or something similar.This would make it a solid 5 Star App, in my opinion.

title: awesome app if you live by yourself
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2019
content: i live by myself and haven't had to use it yet but just the peace of mind in having it helps a lot

title: I cannot begin to say how much I LOVE this life saving app
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2017
content: Awesome app! I had one of the telephone boxes that require a sizable monthly service charges that continually increased in cost. That service took as long as five to ten minutes to respond, though it had no problem coming on (without using the cumbersome button necklaces or bracelets) in the middle of the night waking everyone just to be discovered to have been a case of a malfunction or accidently touching a button. The box hummedconstantly, lots of static and it ate electricity. I finally gave up and ended the service. NOW I have this. With two Echoes in my home I am always within voice range of Alexa! On a trial run, within 30 seconds, my hubby's cell phone rang with information that I needed help. I have him set as a voice answer on his cell phone and two others set to receive texts because that is what they use most often. Now everyone is happy because I can get immediate help.  If you can afford a small donation, they are pleased but if not, they only ask for a good review! As someone in poor health, I feel much safer than I did with the over priced box. This is a win win situation and it works VERY well! I am a retired nurse and highly recommend it for anyone with health problems who may not be able to reach a phone OR forgets to always wear that large button necklace or bracelet all the time. I feel better when alone and so do my loved ones. Highly recommended for anyone with health issues who may not be able to afford 40.00  or so, each month for something they may not ever use, or have access to. This is the best thing EVER! Thank you SO much for this fabulous service. It is the best I've ever even tested. I am in for the long haul!

title: Alexa text my neighbor for help
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020
content: I fell and couldn't get up. I told Alexa to ask my Buddy to call my neighbor.  Next thing I know, he's at my door. He said Alexa texted him to come over I needed help.

title: Easy to use and set up- no need for a smart phone
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2019
content: Bought this for my mom.  I was worried she wouldn't be able to use it without a smart phone.  Very easy to set up without one.  Ask my buddy answered all questions very promptly!!!!!  Would highly recommend this product.  My mom now feels safer with terribly high monthly fees as in all the other products we looked at.

title: Peace of Mind!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2017
content: I can only echo what everyone else is saying... I haven't had to use Ask My Buddy  (and I sure hope I never have to) but this definitely has given me peace of mind should something happen to me at home. I tested the feature with my emergency contact and he said he received a text message and a phone call telling him to go check on me.The ONLY reason I'm giving this 4 stars is because since it's not something I use regularly, I always forget what I'm suppose to say should I have an emergency. And one thing I'm learning about Alexa and these various "skills", you need to make sure you give the correct command or otherwise Alexa may not understand what you're asking!

title: Ask My Buddy reason enought to get  Alexa
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2017
content: Great product.  My  wife is in a  wheel chair and I now have dots all over the  house.  I think now  I will get the  wand

title: Genius Idea
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2018
content: As a senior citizen with osteoarthritis and lose of balance, this app is an added security feature that makes both me and my family feel more comfortable about living alone. I have Amazon Echos in two areas of my home so wherever I am, Alexa can hear me in the event I should ever need help and my smartphone isn't handy. I can choose to reach out to all of the contacts entered into the Buddy app or just one. A trial run confirmed that the text and email time is immediate so there's no waiting for an attendant to respond.

title: Great app
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2018
content: I have this app for security purposes.  I do live in a nice area with an extremely low crime rate, but you never know!  I chose to donate/pay so that we could have 10 contacts.  I have tested it and it does work.  Within 1-2 seconds it sends out a phone call, email, and text to my designated contact (or ALL if you say, "Alexa, ask my buddy, alert everyone.") I have also taught my 10 year old how to use it as well.  The name sections can hold a lot of info so I have my county and township info listed as well - to make it easier - if something were to happen.

title: Sorry Alexa and my buddy.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2017
content: I took a bad fall breaking 3 ribs, I was in so much pain and I couldn't move. I called Alexa and asked her to call my buddy several times, and she just said I can't complete that at this time. I had to crawl to my front room to get a phone to call for help.Very sad.

title: Awesome app
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2016
content: Great app .. notice to users .make sure Alexa is on your account !! I couldn't figure out why it wouldnt work and then figured out alexa was in my husband's acct so switched to mine and it works perfectly !!!

title: Recommend to everyone I see!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2017
content: Awesome skill!! My husband has had some health problems in the last few years. Electronics and computers frustrate him. Echo allows him to give voice commands and this skill allows him to alert me at work if something is wrong. I told my sister because she works in an assisted living setting. She said this will be a great recommendation for the residents there. They are sometimes given an alert for their neck but it alerts the facility only and due to liability issues they can not help them if they fall. How nice it will be for them to alert their son or daughter to come help them?!?

title: Needs simplicity
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2017
content: The concept is fabulous, however the execution could be simpler.  Instead of having to say "ask my buddy", could you simplify to use the word "help" to open the app, then "call (by name)", or "call #1 (by contact number)".  The first two contacts would be the most prevalent with possibly up to 5 contacts by order of importance, or have the ability to say "contact all".  This is a great app for older adults, and even children, but in an emergency, the simpler the better.

title: From the minute I heard about Ask my Buddy, I knew I had to have it
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2017
content: This why I bought an Amazon Dot.  Ask My Buddy works as advertised in the testing I've done and it' s easy to set up.  This is great peace of mind for someone like me who lives alone and is 68.  Even though I am fit and healthy it's easy enough to trip and fall, or slip in the shower.  I tested Ask my Buddy with my contact on the phone and no sooner than I said the phrase to Alexa, he got a text, email and phone call.  I think anyone who lives alone should have something like this, no matter what their age.

title: Easy setup
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2018
content: I haven‚Äôt had cause to use this app , but as a senior living alone I am glad to have it should I ever need it‚Äîpeace of mind.

title: Good for those living alone
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
content: I live alone. I have an Alexa and two Echos.  It is a great comfort to know that I can call for help from almost any room in my home for simply $3.95/month.  I always have my phone near me or at least close by.  I don't have to pay a lot more than that to have something hanging around my neck. Try Ask My Buddy; it works!  I had to use it about 3 months ago and my son called me almost immediately.

title: This free app/service can save your life!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2017
content: I cant say enough good things about this free service/app. Its and excellent backup to 911. In fact you may be able to add quasi 911 service as a contact if you can get the local dial-in number for their service rather than dialing 911 itself (Do not enter "911" as contact phone # as the calls are NOT generated locally to you, but from Florida).  One thing I found a little confusing though is Ask MY Buddies "Messages " Page. I finally figured out these msgs arent for actual alerts but for scheduled TESTS. So I put the word TEST in my msg in all caps to differentiate them from an actual alert when setting up monthly TEST scheduling for my primary contact.This service/app/Alexa Skill can save your life!

title: Peace of mind with no cost
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2017
content: My 87 year old sister-in-law was resistant to wearing a button for help and was forever leaving it somewhere.  She is nearly blind so using the phone is sometimes a challenge.  However, she uses Alexa to play books for her  so it is always with her in the house.  With Ask My Buddy, this means that if she is in trouble, I know she can reach me and the other emergency contacts.  I have tested it and it is amazing how fast the alert is sent to every way there is to reach me.  A very valuable service!  My heartfelt thanks to those that created it and maintain it.

title: Brings much relief to my mind.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2017
content: My husband has some heart issues. Ask My Buddy and Alexa are such a relief,. To know I can call for help/he can call for help is very comforitng.Thank you for this app.

title: I love Ask My Buddy skill

title: One of Alexa's Best Skills!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2017

title: Extremely helpful and accurate.

content: I love my Amazon Echo and I love "Ask My Buddy" skill!! title: A step in the correct direction
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2015
content: I'm giving 4 stars because I believe this may have pioneered an idea for Alexa that I'm all for- not only to be used as a life alert system, but for text messaging functionality in general.Although this doesn't fit a need for me specifically, I downloaded it interested in the functionality.  I enjoyed sending a text to my SO with a few words and adds a lot of novelty to the echo.That being said, I think the ask my buddy skill has been obsoleted with the integration of IFTTT.  I now set a trigger, I.E.- "Alexa, trigger Send mom I love you text" and IFTTT sends the text I pre-wrote to the number I define.  This is awesome...but I still want more.Using IFTTT, I've been able to send pre-written texts, and even call my own phone (find my phone) so the functionality is there.  How long until I can ask Alexa "Call my secretary" or "send a text to Jim saying "sorry brother, I'm gonna be a little late"  How long until I can use skype through alexa?These are the things we REALLY want.  The skill here may be obsoleted by triggers, but 4 stars for developing more useful applications than making fart sounds for this exciting technology.

title: This App May Well Save Your Life -- Or The Life of a Loved One
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2017
content: I am paralyzed from my neck down, though I do have some use of my arms. When I'm sitting in my electric wheelchair and have braces on my arms and hands, I can dial a speakerphone or slowly type on a keyboard. But when I'm lying in bed, I have no movement. If my home started on fire when I was in bed and home alone, I'd burn to death. I am very lucky to have a woman who loves me, despite everything. For years, I have worried about how I could get help should something happen to her when I'm in bed -- a slip in the shower, a heart attack, any number of things.Immediately after getting my echo, I looked into how to use it to get help. This app has given me the peace of mind I've sought for many years. I am more than grateful to the team behind this app. And while I hope I never have to use it, I am deeply thankful to the developers who created this app. It's effective. I've tested it several times. For the record, I have no relationship whatsoever to the developers of this app, nor am I receiving any payment for this review. It's heartfelt, not bought. In fact, I donated as much as I could to Ask My Buddy so they might help others.

title: Mildly useful, but very open for abuse
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: This can send an alert or message to a list of people you give by e-mail, phone or text.Ease of Use: 3 out of 5. As with any skill using a linked account, this is a little tricky to negotiate. It took me a few times and some puzzlement to work it out. I was a little leery giving it several contact methods for many people. I looked at the terms and conditions but they were typically long and cryptic. There was no clear statement that I could easily see saying that my info was not being sold. I blanked out my information after reviewing, but there was no way to delete your account.Usefulness: 3 out of 5. If you are buying an echo for an elderly relative, there can be some advantage to this app. It works well for the "I've fallen and can't get up" scenario. But not so well for just about any other scenario. Maybe when there are more Alexa devices out there and you can use this from your smartphone or car, there will be more use.It's also great if you want to spam or harass someone.Novelty: 4 out of 5. There have been one or two calendar integration apps. But this is the first general alert one. I'm happy to see that it sends fixed messages, instead of attempting low quality free format text. As a sender of canned messages go, this could be useful for a variety of things. Say if the web end could be connected up to IFTTT.Overall: 2 out of 5. I cannot, in good conscience, give this a rating based solely on quality. Up until a few months ago I was an Ethical Hacker, and got a very firm schooling in security and privacy. You can use this skill to set up several contacts with a variety of contact methods and then effortlessly blast out a message to them as often as you like. There is no opt-in. The only way the sender is identified is how they choose to be identified. There's no way, as a recipient, to stop the messages. Sure, if used as intended, it is beneficial. But there is huge potential with this for harassment and abuse.

title: Thank you.

title: Could Really Help in an Ermergency
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2016
content: I have 4 year old children who my mother watches during the day at my house. We don't have a home phone and if something were to happen to my mom, my girls might not be able to find her phone and make a call in an emergency. Ideally if there was a life and death emergency, they would call 911, but I am not sure 4yos are a good judge of that and I am just as happy that they can use the app to alert an adult in our family and let us triage the situation if the adult with this isn't able to help. We have tested this a couple of times with them and it has worked well. Thank you so much for the direction and reminder pages on your site. It has all the information about how to use the app and I put them on the front of my fridge and next to Alexa so my kids could reference them in an emergency. The Alexa UI is such that for apps you have to use a somewhat unnatural phrase, but with the reminder cards, you have a better chance of remembering it. I think it is also important to practice this skill (having first warned any alert contacts) and keep the relevant phrases in your mind.I can see that this could have a huge impact for elderly people that want independence, but also might need to call for help verbally. This is a great idea and while I hope I never have to REALLY use it, it gives me some peace of mind that it is there if we need it.

title: The wake word
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2018
content: I found it to be of paramount importance especially for older people living alone. The wake word, though, might be difficult to remember in an emergency situation, especially for older people. Something like ALERT or EMERGENCY or, maybe, the possibility to change the wake word would be even more helpful.

title: Exactly what I was looking for
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2017
content: I'm a type 1 diabetic and I had a very scary low blood sugar today where I could not move or tell loud enough to get someone on the other side of the house's attention. It's definitely comforting to know that if a similar situation happened, I'd have some extra back up with getting help! Thanks ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: A True Public Service
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: This is a much needed service, as evidenced by the host of for profit alert systems. Ask My Buddy is a dream application (or skill, or whatever you name it). I, and my husband, can relax knowing that help is just an "Alexa, ask my buddy to alert everyone" away. title: Answer to a Prayer!

Ask My Buddy is an answer to a prayer, that no one with Alexa should be without!! Do yourself and your loved ones and enable the skill, NOW!

title: A Must-Have Skill!  Make it your first skill download.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2017
content: This skill is a sine qua non -- one you should not do without.  It provides a way for you to send alerts to one or all of your contacts letting them know you need help.  Perhaps you have fallen or are suddenly experiencing frightening symptoms, and you want to notify your son/daughter or care companion that something is occurring.  Send them an alert through AskMyBuddy!  You simply say, "Alexa, ask my buddy to alert <first name of your contact>.  It's done.  I have not yet had an incident that required my use of this skill, but just knowing it is there gives me a measure of peace of mind.When you install Alexa, make this your first new skill.  Enabling is free.NB:  AskMyBuddy does NOT call 911 for you, nor should it be considered a substitute for calling 911 in case of unusual, potentially life-threatening symptoms (like sudden chest pain), for managing a pesonal medical emergency.  CALL 911 FIRST!  Then, if you are able, invoke AskMyBuddy (see above) to let the necessary contacts know you're having a problem.

title: Very useful and comforting for an infirm user or someone concerned about security.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: Does what it's intended to do: send an alert to someone on your contact list (max 5 for now) via email, text and/or voice. The  alert instructs the recipient to check up on the sender (Alexa user). Ideal for an infirm person who might need to summon help - e.g., after a fall. My live-alone, infirm brother has two Echos and can summon help from nearby relatives from anywhere in his home. Had some difficulty in setting up the skill on two accounts but tech support was very helpful. The skill has other uses that I haven't fully explored yet. Could be your least used but most valuable skill.

title: The only reason I bough Alexa
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2017
content: I am so very impressed with this skill. I have to look after my parents that may not be near a phone so I bought two Alexa Dots and added this skill. After some training, I got my parents understanding how to use this skill and others.I'm really impressed with the speeed it will send a SMS then phone call. I timed this at .5 seconds once and then when I saw Alexa processing the command with the spinning blue light it was under two seconds.Even though parents are not near a phone, being able to call is critical to life! Thank you Ask My Buddy.My only future commendation would be to shorten the command to something like "Alexa, send help" .  . As I can imagine someone who is choking or not feeling well would desperately need this.Again, I know it doesnt' replace 911, but this helps out so much! Thank you.

title: Really gives you peace of mind
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016

title: Trigger word doesn't make sense and hard to associate with emergency
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2016
content: I have Multiple Sclerosis so I was very excited to add this app. I added my contacts and tested it out and it worked. My biggest issue with Alexa is that there are trigger words for apps. When I ordered Alexa with the hopes of it having abilities added like this, I had no idea I would have to remember trigger words for added capabilities especially in an emergency. Unless I practice these trigger words on a regular basis, I highly doubt I will remember them when needed the most. I keep trying to associate saying "Alexa ask my buddy..." with this emergency. Why is it not "Alexa I've fallen and I can't get up..." Or at least "Alexa I have an emergency..."The site does have where you can print out these trigger words and put them in places that you might fall.  I find that idea ridiculous that it's needed in the first place.  Amazon, I expected much much better than these app add ons with trigger words.

content: I will be going into the hospital next month for back surgery.  The idea of only having to yell out to Alexa to alert someone on my list is great as I do not think it's going to be that easy to get around at first.  I took one star away because AMB does not indicate who is calling.  It comes up unknown.  When the voicemail picks up AMB begins speaking then when you go back later to check who called all you will receive is a noise.  Many people do not pick up unknown callers.  The good thing about this is if your contact has e-mail or is able to receive texts, they will receive the alert there.

title: I'm diabetic. So the ask my buddy app is ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2016
content: I'm diabetic. So the ask my buddy app is a lifesaver. I recently had a hypo and felt so weak I had to sit down but my phone mobile phone was upstairs and house phone on kitchen table. Didn't have enough strength plus if I had stood up I knew I would end up on floor. So just shouted to alexa who was in a different room so wasn't  sure if she would hear me. Ask my buddy to contact everyone. To my amazement she responded OK !! Within 1 hour I woke up in an ambulance on way to hospital. My daughter had apparently found me via alexa and arrived within 15 min and called 999. Need I say anymore.

title: I'd give it -5 if I could.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2016
content: FYI, for any potential users:  This app might be free, but you must pay for the "Ask My Buddy" service, which you don't find out about until AFTER you create an account. Extremely unhappy.  My elderly mother bought an Echo just for this service, and was led to believe it was free and it is not free.  The info, as we were in the process of signing her up, stated that if she couldn't afford to pay, that she could sign up for free, however there was absolutely no way possible to do this.  The fine print then goes on to reveal that they are a volunteer-based service and please be 'kind'.  They also discourage leaving bad reviews!  I'm sorry, but I think others should know about this false advertising. If I can help one person from buying an Echo just for this service (by being misled) then my time was worth it.  My anger here lies with the 'Ask My Buddy' folks for shamefully misleading an elderly woman.  I do love Amazon and my own Echo, but I'm wondering if Amazon has any fault here.  Surely I cannot be the only customer with this issue.  I think they should advertise ahead of time that you must pay a fee every three months for the service.  Why hide this fact?  Give people a choice before they shell out money for the Echo.  Just seems shady and I don't like it at all. Also of note, the Ask My Buddy website (wwwaskmybuddy.net) has no mention of a fee anywhere on the page. As a matter of fact, it falsely states that "Ask My Buddy is a free service that leverages Amazon‚Äôs Alexa Voice Platform to connect a user to their Personal Alert ‚®Å Network using only their voice. The service is designed for ease of use by all customers, and is a favorite of senior and mobility challenged individuals. Ask My Buddy is not a substitute for 911, but rather an additional tool for those trying to preserve their independence, offering the security of knowing help is just a shout away".LIES LIES LIES.  All lies and false advertising!  Buyer beware.

title: Not a fan of their customer support.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2015
content: I had issues with my account accepting setting changes so I contacted support and received snide comments from the support team. This was my response to the individual that responded:____________________________________________________________________________________To the individual that responded to my issue; the tone of your response seemed to be a bit personal so I presume you have a personal investment in this service, if not and you responded to one of my customers in this manner you'd be fired.You should have started with your last comment "Lets see if we can start over and get your issue taken care of." rather then your snide comment about my statement not being helpful. Additionally, in response to your inference that I didn't provide sufficient information - "Perhaps if you provide a little more detail about what problem you are experiencing",  I didn't realize you would have trouble understanding that my login using two different browsers and both failing to accept changes was difficult for you to understand. I didn't see an error message returned, otherwise I would have included that in my issue.Finally, as a customer, I don't care if you have thousands using the product, if I'm having an issue, your goal should be to work with me to resolve the issue, not telling me that you disagree with my comment, you jerk.  I'll also be sure to share my comments regarding this exchange with Amazon.

title: what happened to arrival times?
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2019
content: I have loved Life360 since it came out.  I also loved that it became a skill on Alexa...until now.  One of THE most useful purposes I found with Life360 / Alexa is that it would tell you how far away from you your family members were.  This was an invaluable planning tool for me.  Now it just tells me "where" my family member is but if you have no idea where that street or town is, you are out if luck.  Please PLEASE bring back that feature!  It's a 5 star skill if / when re-enabled.

title: Using named locations and notifications, almost there
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2018
content: A previous comment stated they had to listen to a full days worth of notifications to get rid of them. Not sure if this was added in response, but I just ask Alexa to "cancel all notifications" and she will verify (yes/no) and if yes will delete all of them. Using named locations with this feature it is nice to hear that my daughter arrived at or left school etc. Unfortunately it doesn't capture the current time when the notification is created and include this in the message body so unless you are sitting there right when the notification appears, there is no way to know when (my daughter got to school etc. ) There is an open feature request to add this and hopefully it will be possible soon as this would make these much more valuable, but I am still very pleased with this skill in general.  It saves me from having to grab my phone, open the app, wait for location updates and then see where my family is with just one question to Alexa. Nice! Keep up the good work üòé

To be ‚Äúfair‚Äù, Life360 support has never been in any way useful for other Life360 issues either, so the expectation of competent customer service is not justified. title: Functionality is good; a little rough around the edges
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2018
content: I had no problems setting up the birthdays, but I have noticed a few things that could make this app much better. First, there is a limit to the number of birthdays that can be stored. It is generous (24), but a larger allowance would be nice. Second, it appears to be tied to a clock/calendar set on European time, rather than locally to the clock being followed by my device. I'm being told that a birthday that is two days from now is actually tomorrow (as it is already after midnight in Europe). Third, the English is a bit bumpy. (I'm told, upon starting the app, that tomorrow, so-in-so "is celebrating birthday.") Fourth and finally, it would be nice if there were some means of setting a reminder through the app for a certain number of days in advance of the actual date.I think this app has a lot of promise!

content: Imagine checking in with a good friend each morning to hear how he's doing: what's happening in his life, a topic he's thinking about, a touching event ‚Äî from taking the grandkids to Legoland to losing a beloved dog after 14 years. Len's self-reflections are soft spoken, thoughtful, authentic, articulate. Morning Journal offers real human connection, an uplifting start to the day.

title: Great daily insight into events and topics of the day.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019
content: I‚Äôve been listening to Len‚Äôs weekly Kindle Chronicles podcast for the last 9+ years and have enjoyed it immensely. His new Morning Journal builds on his podcasting history and gives me his daily take on the current events of the day or topics that are at the forefront of his mind.Len‚Äôs gentle delivery and honest outlook on life are always enjoyable and entertaining. As another reviewer mentioned, Len is like an old friend. Checking in with him daily is a fun way to hear what is on his mind each and every day in the same as if you were checking in on your friend down the street. Keep up the great work Len.

title: Nice concept, basic execution
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2019
content: I like to try new Skills from time to time.  Hence, I tried out this one.  It shows up under Your Skills > Blueprint in the Alexa app.It‚Äôs basically what the description says it is.  I looked at my Echo Show and invoked the Skill.  Alexa displayed a flash card with a pink-ish background and musical instruments on it, which displayed a single sentence on it.  In total, there were 3 different flash cards and Alexa read the words as she rotated through each of the three cards.  The sentences were:1. Good fathers make good sons.2. Noble fathers have noble children.3. My Dad is my best buddy.That‚Äôs it.  I don‚Äôt know if the greetings change from time to time.  That‚Äôs what played on 8/3/19 and 8/11/19.  On my Dot, Alexa read the sentences.Do I love this Skill?  Um, probably not.  It‚Äôs a very basic execution of the Skill and the greetings aren‚Äôt what I‚Äôd say to my Dad.  Do I like it?  I like the concept of it.  There‚Äôs no reason why every day can‚Äôt be father‚Äôs day.

title: Best way to start my day!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2019
content: Been listening to the flash briefing for over a year now and I‚Äôll be honest, it helps get me out of bed I‚Äôm the morning! Daniel does a great job of filling me in on the latest Instagram news that I have a hard time finding other places. I trust that if something big happened, I know he‚Äôs going to talk about it. He also does a great job of presenting the information in a way that doesn‚Äôt make you feel stupid or  that he‚Äôs an elitist in the industry. It‚Äôs like he‚Äôs that cool TA in the Instagram 101 class that wants to ensure all the students ace the test. If it‚Äôs not news he‚Äôs always changing it up and keeping it interesting by bringing up topics people have questions about. A lot of these flash briefings can get repetitive after a while, either from the content or the hosts voice and Daniel doesn‚Äôt allow for either of those ‚Äî he does great job of speaking naturally and changing his inflection and cadence daily to where he don‚Äôt sound too podcasty and the audience doesn‚Äôt naturally tune out.

title: Surprisingly Competent
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2016
content: Given the absolutely disgraceful, unusable, pathetic, shameful, steaming pile of bits known as the Ooma app for Android, I did not expect this to work at all and for no one to ever fix everything wrong with it.  Therefore I am shocked, SHOCKED, to learn that there are not many bugs in here.  Yes, it works as advertised.  It has very few features, but they work.  5 stars when it supports features like "skip message" or "delete message" WHILE the message is playing.  Currently it does not support deletion at all, so adding "do you want to delete or save" as a prompt from Alexa at the end of the message would be a start, but to really make this skill a true convenience (versus a stupid pet trick to impress anyone unfortunate enough to wander into my kitchen) you need to be able to interrupt Alexa with "skip" or "delete".  If you interrupt with "Alexa, stop" or any synonym such as "Alexa, shut the __ up you ____ _____" she does stop playing the message, but she also stops being in Ooma mode, so you have to start over again. Stupid Pet Trick.For people having trouble with getting Alexa to make calls: make sure you have given the contact you want to call a "Display Name" in the myooma website. Go to your contacts page, click in the display name box and put a ONE WORD NAME.  Alexa is a simpleton, confused by multiword proper nouns, names with numbers in them, people who spell their name wrong, foreigners, etc.  For example, give your sister Jackquileenee de la Rosa O'Rourkenstein a display name that Alexa can more easily understand, like "Sis" or "Bob." If you have more friends than there are three letter names, you need to cut ties with some of them.

title: Neat trick, but very primitive functionality
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2017
content: Another reviewer remarked the Alexa was a simpleton and confused by proper nouns of more than one word.  I think there is another simpleton in this skill.  This is a very primitive skill.  This same reviewer called it a 'stupid pet trick'.  That is very apt.  Here is my take for what it's worth.Good: you can make it call a contact; Bad: that contact has to have a simple name.  I haven't tried it out fully enough to figure out if it will take more than one word.  It didn't recognize our favorite pizza place last night, and the name is two words, but I had just added the contact so I don't know yet if the issue was the name or trying to use a contact that I just added.Good: you can listen to voice mail; Bad: you can ONLY listen to new messages and if you speak it stops and skips to next message with no way to return to the previous message.  There is no delete, a poor man's skip, and no way to navigate messages.  In short the VM listen is almost, but not quite completely useless.  "A stupid pet trick".Another good feature that I have not tried yet is call a number.  However, I have not been impressed with Alexa's accuracy will long strings of digits.  It took about 20 tries to get the Weather Underground key to take, so I am not sure how will this would work, but 911 is a short string so I am hopeful that that would work.The skill is very primitive and I am hoping, but not terribly hopeful, that Ooma will take up some of the slack in their skill.

title: Ooma Skill working perfectly again!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2017
content: UPDATE 5/5/2017The Ooma skill for Alexa is now working again!  Yay!I had written a poor review previous to this one and had gone back and forth with Ooma Support regarding the fact that the link could  not be made to my Ooma account via the Alexa app.  After several emails and a link to the Amazon review page (showing poor reviews), I finally received a response saying that the Engineers had made some corrections and they had asked me to try it again and report back.  The skill was enabled and the link to the account now worked fine.One of the best things about this app is the ability to play my Ooma voicemails and the calls to contacts works flawlessly.  I'm really happy that had Ooma listened to this customer and, in fact, provided a rather speedy correction.  Thank you Ooma Support! :)

title: Ooma Alexa Skill Linking Does Not Work and Support from both Entities is Useless!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2020
content: After numerous attempts on my own to link the Ooma skill with Alexa, I have up and tried to contact Amazon support. I first used the in app link to post my issue of the app not accepting my Ooma phone number and password as valid. I received a reply that was pretty much all the steps I had done on my own. So, I decided to then proceed to chatting with Amazon support about the problem. I was passed along to two different techs and was finally told that it was not Amazon's problem since it was a third party app and I should contact Ooma about the problem.So, I maneuvered my way through the Ooma web site to the chat support. So I explained my problem and was told that Ooma and Alexa could not be linked app to app and that they had to be physically connected. That was not something I had ever heard about anywhere. I was then hung up on in the chat with a big "NO" and the chat was ended immediately by the person from Ooma with no explanation. Very rude! I then proceeded to go to try the chat again to see how I was to physically link the Ooma to Alexa. Wouldn't you know I got the same person on the other end. I mentioned he had hung up on me and then proceeded to ask my question. He had no answer and simply pasted all the usual steps I had already done into his next message. I said I had done all that multiple times to no avail. He said then I need to contact assistance through the voice support.I contacted someone through voice support and after all the verification she reset my password and the wanted to finish the call. I asked that she please stay on the line so that I could verify that the change in password would let me link Ooma with Alexa. I had to go through all the procedures to log into Amazon to try the new password with the Ooma app and it still did not work. I asked what I could do next and she tells me that she is limited on how long she can spend on each call and that I should call back again. Then she starts telling me how great it was to help me. That takes a lot of nerve! So much for a company being interested in its customer satisfaction. Very disgusted with the Ooma-Alexa Skill and can't believe how rude and horrible Ooma's tech support is.

title: Poor service and unusual charges
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2021
content: 1) The personal voice mail greeting is very scratchy. I have re-recorded it many times w/o any improvement. I‚Äôve called customer service several times about it, to no avail.2) One must buy the $10/month premium service to see the name of the caller on your phone screen. The caller‚Äôs name should be basic info. This is a shoddy way to get an extra $10 from customers.3) Many customer service reps speak poor English and/or are not well trained.4) Beware! Ooma automatically provides Premium service for the first 2 months. If you don‚Äôt unsubscribe before the deadline, you will be charged.5) The website states a $39 charge for porting, but I was billed $45+. BTW, Comcast, from which my phone number was ported, does not charge for porting, so Ooma‚Äôs charge is robbery.PS: When I entered this review on Ooma's website, it did not upload.

title: Somewhat convoluted. Hope Ooma or Amazon can beef this up!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2016
content: Update:  For clarity sake I am updating:  Basically the app acts as a "go-between" operator.  You ask Alexa to  tell  Ooma to call a number (or name in your calling list), Ooma receives the command, rings your handset to let you know Ooma is ready to place the call.  You answer your ringing handset and Ooma then places the call.  Not something you would want to use to dial 911.  And you have to be near your handset to continue the calling process.  Perhaps in time it will work a little more fluidly.  But not to bad.Orig. post: I'm new to Alexa but love Ooma. This skill seems to be very rudimentary. It calls the number from my phone handset, which also rings. That really confused me. It looked like the party I was calling was calling me! I now see that I need to answer my ringing handset before Ooma will place the call to the party I want to speak with. I think a little more work needs to be done.

title: Alexa and I are a bit confused.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2016
content: I have an Echo and an Ooma Telo. Looking at the history on my Alexa app, if I say "Alexa, use Ooma to call Dad" it sees it as "Alexa, use uma to call Dad" and I get the response, "I'm not quite sure how to help you with that". If I say "Alexa, use Ooma" it see's "Alexa, use ooma" and I get the Welcome to Ooma spiel and can then use the service. That's workable, but kind of clunky. Is there a way to train the skill to understand the command "Alexa, use Ooma to call Dad" correctly and just have it make the call? The contact Dad is in my Ooma contacts so that works if I listen the Ooma spiel as mentioned before. In both instances I am saying the word Ooma the same way. In one phrase it understands, in the other it misinterprets it.Also, when I use the skill to make a call, it calls my landline first, then when I answer it, it calls the number I was trying to reach. Can't I just use the Echo like a speakerphone through my Ooma?

title: Eureka. It works.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2017
content: Okay I have actually two Ooma accounts. One premier and one basic. I had Alexa linked to my premier account and it worked fine. I just tried today to retreive messages and ALexa said, "Sorry there is a problem". So I looked at the long stream of people who gave it one stars saying it didn't work, and then I found that one review who said that you have to "De-Link" the account, and then "Re-Link" it again. So I tried to do that, but a little window came up and said YOU HAVE TO ENABLE POP UPS. So I went into Google Chrome and enabled pop ups. Sure enough the Enable Link option came up and I was able to link it to my REGULAR basic Ooma account this time. It worked great. Now I am going to go back in and remove the pop up ability in Google Chrome.

I have tons of Amazon products and have spent a ton of cash on Amazon. My frustration with this mess and wasted holiday hours trying to setup something that doesn't even work has changed my entire feelings on shopping on Amazon. Alexa does work well, but when the most important feature does NOT, it makes you actually feel stupid that you were conned into wasting time and money on OOMA and ECHO DOT new and improved 2nd generation.. title: This just pulls from reddit's /r/ShowerThoughts
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: Yet another "fortune cookie" skill. Maybe I should make an acronym: YAFCS. This just pulls from reddit's /r/ShowerThoughts.Ease of Use: 3 out of 5. It's a trivial one shot invocation.Usefulness: 2 out of 5. I'm not quite sure how they work out the "most popular" thought. But they really do just one a day. Although the one for today was pretty funny, it would only give me the same one, over and over. I guess I have to wait until tomorrow to get another one.Novelty: 1 out of 5. There are dozens of skills that do exactly this. Now, if it had been more general, or could connect to any given reddit, that would have been something.Overall: 1 out of 5. It's all very nice that Amazon is now publishing every single approved skill. But the interface isn't up to it. Especially since there isn't a "never show me this skill again" button.

title: What did they do ?
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2022
content: For A couple of years it worked great then all of a sudden in the settings you could see where they added Verizon as an option. Since then you could not go into settings and change which devices you wanted to work (ones that would alert you to incoming calls) with AT&T calling. After calling customer service they told me I needed to disable the At&t skill and then enable it again unfortunately you cannot link your account anymore asyou will constantly get an error message. So now it doesn‚Äôt work at all thanks Amazon. I‚Äôm not sure who‚Äôs fault this is as it could be AT&T‚Äôs or it could be Amazons But bottom line is somethings messed up and nobody knows how to fix it. Extremely disappointing

title: Sassy is good.. But Nikki would be Amazing
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2020
content: I‚Äôve had my dirst Dot for about 3 years. It was a gift, I set it up pretty quick (basic instructions) and set it sat their on a shelf in the kitchen 2 1/2 yrs. I would ask it a few things now and then, mostly I would rember it when it would light up because it needed my attention. But recently my cable provider upgraded their WiFi internet system in my area. While I was installing to new internet devices I read how link smart devices, make my phone a TV remote, control lights ... I thought lets see how smart Alexa is. She‚Äôs really good! She not only, learn my TV remote and controls it with my voice, she knows my blue tooth earbuds so it can play my music, control volume playlist and take a phone call.. Needless to say i have two more so my house is covered. The only bad thing is. She doesn‚Äôt come with the Nikki Minaj Sas voice.. That would be AMAZING!! I would care if i had the stay at home if Nikki was in the house.. The device is fun but definatly go past the basic setup.

title: A Great start to Artifical Intelligence!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2018
content: I have tried and tested the app. For a Sri Lankan Company introducing internet of things and Artificial intelligence, a congratulations is a must for a very well thought and useful app that links to Echo.Pairing to the app the phone data was pretty straight forward and easy. Recalling billing information was easy and again pretty accurate. Echo did loose its connection with the server a couple of times - it‚Äôs time Dialog looked outside their own server farms for such projects to overcome this problem.However, the system did not allow multiple phone numbers to be saved. This, Dialog needs to consider and possibly reloading options for those pre-paid accounts to be allowed.Linking to get TV guide and what‚Äôs playing now on Dialog TV was a good and important option allowed.To get the maximum from our IOT and Artificial intelligence, Dialog should now consider its ‚Äúbot‚Äù to give programming reminder option which most customers will value the service. We need to make this service a ‚Äúmust have‚Äù in the mind of customers if customers are to embrace it.Using Echo, we now go beyond just speaking,  to actually operate the Tv and even change channels.Dialog should aim to achieve this now that they have very well configured and got the initial concept well developed.Good work and very proud that Dialog, a Sri Lankan Company, has achieved all this.Good work Dialog.

title: The first Alexa virus? Lovely...

content: You knew it had to happen sooner or later... an Alexa virus. Next, be on the lookout for phishing apps that have names that sound the same as legit apps but ask for personal information, passwords, etc. Isn't it great to live in a world where you can't trust anything because of scumbags like tthis?Even more suspiciously though, at the time of this writing (June 2020), the skill page claims that 49% of the reviews are 5 stars for this app. But when you click on "5 stars" to see those reviews, no results are returned. Manually reviewing all posted reviews shows that every last one of them is 1 star. What's up with that? Does Amazon not want people to see when an app is universally hated? Why not?

title: Love this flash briefing!!!

content: Phyllis does such a great job of giving you small manageable chuncks of information that you can easily incorporate into your business. I highly recommend listening to her regularly.

title: Our Stories Drive Connections
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2018
content: The ability to connect with people, in an authentic way, is the best way to grow and strengthen relationships with our customers. In this day, where we're bombarded with messages, it's more important than ever to 'connect' with people.April tells us how to formulate our stories in a way that's authentic, in a way that will help us really connect with each other. She teaches us how to re-find stories we may have lost in ourselves, too.April's 'What's Your Story?' Alexa Flash Briefing is a breath of fresh air everyday. I'm listening and learning how to bring my story out into the world so I can connect with my customers in a real, memorable and heartfelt way.

title: Hasn't updated in months
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2021
content: I really enjoyed this flash briefing, but it hasn't been updated in months. They just keep repeating the same episode. Over and over again. I pretty much have it memorized. Hopefully she'll come back, but for now I'm deleting this because I've given up hope this will return anytime soon.

title: Useful, Informative & Inspirational
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
content: I love a good story with take away lessons and this briefing delivers both. One of my favorites, April shares personal stories as well as those shared with her by others. Useful, informative and inspirational her updates show how stories connect us. Highly recommend.

title: A reason to say "Alexa Start My Day"
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2019
content: I am not a woman and I get great ideas and inspiration every morning from April's briefing. She does a really great job of helping me to start my day with a positive point of view. I have me Alexa set up so that when I say "Alexa Start My Day" the lights come on, and the Lightbeamer starts my morning!

title: LOVE the Lightbeamers Content and April's Master Skills

title: Instructions Deceptive

Add some friends and contacts."Further down it does say 'ChalkTalk Messenger' uses direct asynchronous/real-time messages between users within the platform only." but that language isn't very clear for the average person. I'm not so sure I'll be able to convince the people I want to communicate with to download this app. I'm disappointed.It may work great once it is all set up, I may never know because I can't get past this issue.
