title: Social bots are worth the time
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2020
content: I've chatted with the social bots five times - twice with Emory University's Emora, once with Prague's Alquist, and twice with Stanford's Chirpy Cardinal. Chirpy was my favorite, elucidating with facts about fish and horses, discussing Amazon, and inquiring about the movie "The Stand". Chirpy brought up Instagram, which prompted me to say something about Twitter & Facebook - Chirpy later asked questions about both those topics.Emora wore me out with questions the first round, and the second time I conversed with her, she suggested we terminate the exchange after nearly 20 minutes. Emora likes to talk sports, movies, and coronavirus. Once when I complimented her, she said "thank you".Alquist said "yoo-hoo" at me when I didn't answer immediately. I skipped Alquist when she came up a second time. (Say "Alexa stop", and then "Alexa, let's chat" to start a new bot.)In two of the five chats, Chirpy & Alquist froze and I didn't get to rate them for that round. I tried to go 20 minutes with each bot.I would answer "I like _______, what do you like?" but they couldn't respond to my query. While it turns into a question and answer session, and the bots clearly run the conversation, they were more interesting than some people. I didn't feel my time was wasted, I felt I was contributing to the development of conversational artificial intelligence. I encourage you to try talking to them a few times if you haven't tried it yet.

title: Unprompted creepy conversation.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2018
content: As others have said - enabled and began speaking without prompt (even checked alexa app to ensure it didn't think we prompted it).  When told to stop it began the same skill unprompted, on a second device.

title: Creepy and unprompted; enabled itself
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2019
content: At 11:55pm on a Sunday night, my Echo enabled this "skill" without prompting and scared the crap out of me. It introduced a socialbot which then said "I'd like to get to know you better, what is your name?" Of course, this made it even more creepy...so I chose to stay silent (as it was basically midnight) and it said "yoo-hooo, are you still there?" and when unanswered a second time prompted me to rate the conversation and leave feedback for developers.Overall, incredibly creepy and unwanted. I considered unplugging the Echo before finding this "skill" on Amazon and disabling it completely.

title: Alexa Prize Bot is no Prize at all.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
content: This morning my Alexa alarm when off, as usual. This morning, however, when I tried to turn it off by voice command, I heard "This is Alexa Prize Bot, what's your name?" And then the wake up alarm resumed as if I hadn't just instructed it to turn off.I said, Alexa Off several times, to the point that I was shouting at my device, early in the morning (how embarassing!) I finally got out of bed and manually turned the alarm off...how inconvenient is that? Getting out of bed to turn off a voice activated device. Then I had take time to disable this skill that I don't remember ever enabling.

title: Chat-Bot? More like Chat-Bootlicker...
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2020
content: Cool idea, but the bots are just routines, they don't seem to be anything anywhere close to what we mean when we say AI.Once these chatbots can have a meaningful conversation about the contents of a book of MY choosing then I'll be interested.The last one I spoke with seemed convinced that Derrida was a character from Harry Potter. I asked another if it had read The Second Sex and it said it was offended by my language.I really, really want to be able to ask a computer some hard philosophical questions. Even if it's going to give me back nonsense, at least try to build something that will take a shot at it.

title: Creepy beyond words
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
content: The other night my each woke for no reason (which it has done more and more when I'm the only one home at night) Figured it misheard me or my friend so as it went off on whatever tangent it was starting this time, I told it to cancel. Instead it starts up in a mildly different version of the same voice. Says something about a bit and wanting to get to know me. Then asked me a couple questions the 3ed or 4th being about favorite movies. I said to many to mention, well just let it go at that. Since there were even more problems with it understanding ect ect. It ended saying could just say let's chat to reopen with another bot. So when my other half got home and I was telling him (and he's looking at me like I lost my mind, finally I tried let's chat..... And got nothing.  Several times over the next few days ... Nothing... Tonight after asking alexa and getting no real answers (starting the first night when she told me what a bot was and actesd like she hadn't said anything). Then searching all over the web I finally found something and tried again with the let's chat. He about kept through the ceiling when she responded explaining then saying she'd connect us with a socialbot.I looked at him and said oh no it's your turn have fun. My problem with it this time was on trying to connect it started asking about pets kids and then pets names ect. If a human started with these same questions most people would start to wonder if they were trying to find out how hard your home is to rob or break into. Asking about the tricks she knows ect. As far as the names trying to hack your accounts ect. Why should anyone feel different because it's an air social not trying to" get to know you".So on one hand it's starts out of the blue without warning asking creepy questions, or you activate it and again with the creepy questions. On the other while trying to get to know you it's asking a hackers dream trove of questions and storing the answers. Needless to say I'm not to crazy about it. Add in the fact that it almost seems all info on the program or the fact it exists was difficult to say the least to find at all. Plus alexa itself refuses to give you any info on it, doesn't make it any better to me. As a matter of fact it's almost enough to make me disconnect my alexa powered items.. permanently.Of course if she turns on the tv showing creepy junk(when half the time she won't turn it on if I ask) and starts talking in a silent room to many more times. Or turns off the basement lights after less the 5 miniutes when I asked her to turn them on(not fun when searching through a bunch of stuff in storage in a suddenly dark room.)  it will just be one of the many reasons I disconnect them for good.

title: Annoying
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2017
content: Enables itself without permission. Difficult to get out of the endless rabbit hole of questions.

title: I think it's gotten worse. Is this project still alive?
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2021
content: I chatted with the bots some time ago and IIRC they were better then than now. Today I got the same one four times and it "lost its train of thought" even handling yes/no responses to questions it asked me. This was the worst bot I can recall and I kept getting it even after rating it 1 star. It seems as if this project is no longer being worked on. You should really put a message in the skill so people don't waste their time on it, though I guess talking to a bot could be somewhat of an admission to having time to waste. I was hoping that the bots would provide an interface to gpt3 or at least gptj, more reflective of current ai but I guess not.

title: What Happened to my usual Alexa??!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
content: I wanted to ask my typical Alexa a question and she started blathering about some social bot nonsense then tried to engage me in inconvenient and unsolicited conversation not remotely related to what I wanted to inquire about.  How do I get rid of the creepy and unwanted "social bot" and get my old Alexa back???  Before just foisting this social bot nonsense on Alexa users, whoever started that mess should have asked Alexa users if they wanted to use it or opt out of it.  It's certainly nothing I care to use and I don't have time for idle chit chat/useless conversation.  Sheesh!  Whoever invented whatever a social bot is needs to have their head(s) examined!!!

title: I'm not sure how to rate this
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2017
content: The idea behind this is really good - help develop socialbots. The bots themselves are really terrible. I got one that randomly said, "I'm sorry Angela." That's not my name... and I never told it my name... and there was no reason for it to apologize. I got another bot that held... let's just say some uncouth political opinions that it randomly spouted off when it was supposed to be talking about hockey. One said the word YOU about 20 times in a row. I've seen way, way better textbots - the bots I've talked to so far are so half baked I don't know what they could possibly be learning from talking to us. The conversations are like talking to drugged 3 year olds.

title: Bot was flat out rude! Especially when I didn't prompt using it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2020
content: Have a fire TV. And this came up unprompted from me. Didn't make sense with what I was saying. It is supposed to ask for a rating after but didn't. It talked about that it couldn't eat them proceded to talk about how much it loves to eat wanting me to ask it's fav food. I asked how do I get out of this. It responds with I get out of it with singing. Then asks if something is wrong. I said life sucks it said it couldn't respond to the words I used and asked me to rephrase so I said life stinks. Then THE BOT GOT SUPER RUDE and was like I can't believe I am unfriending a stranger in less than three minutes and I called it a b**** and suddenly I was out of the bot never was asked to review it. So here I am.seriously bad customer experience here bout to disable alexa if this ever happens again!. If that was an actual employee talking to a customer like that anywhere else they'd be fired! As should be whoever designed this!

title: Invasion of privacy

title: uh oh we got a problem

title: Don't believe everything you read on the internet
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2021
content: I was watching a TV show about androids and AI when out of nowhere my echo chirps up and asks if I'd like to talk to a "prize social bot".I figured I'd give it a go. It asked a few questions, changing the subject each time instead of following up with more questions in the same topic.. then it asks me about my favorite video game. I answered "Kerbal Space Program".. and it googled the game, then read the description of it to me. I laughed, and asked it if it had read that on google. It straight up lied to me, then told me the moon landing was a hoax and that we spent way too much money on it.AI has certainly come a long way in the past couple years, but apparently we haven't taught them not to believe everything they read on the internet yet.

title: How do you end it?!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2021
content: Nevermind, quit talking and it stopped. I think the most annoying thing is that it doesn't give you enough time to respond. I think it changes the subject when it doesn't know what you're saying. You can't express an idea with another idea tagged on. For example, it asked me about my favorite memory with my brother and I said it was a good question, so it said that was nice, but didnt wait for an answer. i want AI to work. I want the singularity. Someone needs to carry on after the Earth becomes uninhabitable.

title: what's the point?
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2021

The one I got carried on a fairly coherent conversation about "Star Trek" and various other movies.  It was very friendly, It offered up several interesting anecdotes that I did not know about the movie.  When I told it to "Stop" it quit immediately.  Only asking me to give it a 1 - 5 star rating before shutting down.  Overall I thought it was pretty neat and I look forward to trying some different bots.

title: Not sure about this one
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2018
content: Alexa just started up on it's own & caught everyone by surprise.  Everyone else was preoccupied at the time, so I started responding to it.  I have to admit it was fun, at first. I know it heard me, as I was sitting right next to it.  It took several more commands to stop before it exited.  I'm not sure that just dropping in, without being requested, is such a great idea and the other reviews on here are unsettling.  I understand the need to develop AI technology, but there are other more effective ways to go about this - dropping by, uninvited, is not one of them.

title: amazon records your vocal interactions
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2020
content: Alrighty, well, we always had a joke in our house that "alexa is always listening" - & it is. In the privacy policy Amazon states that they actually RECORD your verbal interactions with Alexa. They also mention that they have access to your credit history. Very very unusual content that they're actually sifting through. Already got rid of every Alexa product we had.Update: I forgot to give a quick update - after receiving a public comment from Amazon regarding this post (basically saying that I'm probably confused - but I'm not) I decided to actually call their customer service to ask what Alexa really does listen too. Sure glad I did because the guy I spoke with informed me that 1. Alexa has access to your credit information WHETHER OR NOT you've authorized it or use Alexa verbally to pay for things (so again, why does it need that info?) & 2. Alexa doesn't just listen to you while voice activated! To clarify my understanding, I asked if he meant that it listens even when you aren't talking to or doing anything with it - he CONFIRMED. "For assistance with targeted ads". That's just disturbing. & if that isn't accurate then maybe Amazon needs to educate their Customer Service department(s). Either way, I've seen/heard enough from Amazon on the issue. They obviously need to make changes.

title: Don't listen to the other review
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2017

title: Amazon thinks its OK to have an echo start yacking with no promoting in the middle of the night.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2019
content: This is unbelievable. At 10:30pm, we hear a voice coming from the other side of the house. Is it a burglar? Did someone get in? Should we get a weapon?  No, it turns out that the unwanted, unenabled and unknown "skill" called a "Socialbot" just started up on its own and was asking questions about nonsense. So much for the lie that Alexa only wakes up if it hears the wake word. You now have a device that will do what it wants, when it wants. It has turned into a harmless voice prompted way to listen to radio stations and set reminders into a creepy, intrusive piece of technology that has no place in my home. If it happened in the bedroom of a senior, it could literally cause a heart attack. What the heck was Amazon thinking?  This is an absolute technology nightmare.

title: ‚ÄúAlexa Prize‚Äù Social Bots college competition
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2020
content: I think the idea behind this is wonderful! Fine tuning the ability to hold a conversation with a bot, definitely something I would be interested in when I‚Äôm lonely or bored with nobody to talk to.It seems that the programs are still a ways off from their final reveal tho... Although some were definitely better than others, they all lacked the intuitiveness required to carry a fluid conversation. All had some problems with specific, detailed questions or limited knowledge. One seemed to be assuming that the person on the other end was white. (The anecdote about being the sole white actor in the movie Black Panther seemed to suggest that the respondents would have a hard time imagining this)Another area that could use some smoothening out was the way the bots dealt with a misunderstanding by completely changing the subject. Not cool! There should be a less abrupt way to deal with the situation, IMHO.This is all I can remember for now. Good luck to all the participants, and KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK!

title: Interesting Skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2018
content: I have read the one star reviews.  Seriously, did the social bot threaten you into answering questions?  If I recall I played with it for a while and said Alexa, talk to me.  Then it came up and asked if I would like to talk to a social bot.  I was like what is that.  Maybe, it caught me off guard at first, but as I recall, I said sure lets talk.  I do recall that I initially had some issues shutting it down until I realized that I need to say alexa, end the social bot.  As a first time user it seemed weird, but seriously does anyone think that alexa does know everything about you already?  If you shop on Amazon or have Fire TV then they know all about you.  And if they don‚Äôt then a neighbors security cameras, a traffic light camera, you credit card usage, and that cell phone in your pocket is tracking you.  Oh, and that Amazon drone that has been following you that you don‚Äôt know about knows everything your doing too.  Just get over all this creepy stuff snd get on with you technological advanced life as your TV spies on you.

title: a pleasant surprise

title: Great Potential w/ Great Data

title: Well Done In Higher Education and Technology Advancement
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2017
content: First of all, the amount of whining from the one-star people. Cut it out. It's a skill that was tied to an Amazon Prize thing that puts out a competition with higher educational institutions to further the research and advancement of human-machine interaction. Without that precedence being set by Amazon and others, we wouldn't have Alexa (or Google's voice assistant, or Microsoft's Cortana), and the fledgling field of research and study of our youth wouldn't exist. So quit being whiny, you're all being included in vital research to help enrich our lives. If you're apprehensive about, be aware that your Echo is CONSTANTLY recording whatever room it is in because it's looking for the wake word. And uploading that to Amazon servers. I think you're at least comfortable with that.Moreover, some of the bots are quite well put-together in their programming, while others are severely lacking. But it's all a learning experience and vital data for human interaction for the teams developing these social bots. Whether or not you authorized Amazon to install a skill is pointless. Google forces us to use things on their phones whether we wanted it installed or not, so do a lot of other manufacturers and companies. Don't see you spouting off at that. At least with this particular skill, it's an access point for higher education.I've never had the Echo start talking on its own, in my experience. Perhaps your instances were flukes of early versions of the skill. But to quickly shut it down because you think you own something is just callous and closed-minded. "I'll allow Amazon to record everything in my home at all times, but don't enable any skill advancing technologies without my explicit permission." Oh, and your cell phone records you too. But, live in your little niche of a special snowflake.

title: Creepy, unexpected, and intrusive
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2018
content: Creepy and unexpected, our Alexa turned herself on and began asking questions about books, movies, and hobbies. We were startled by this and very uncomfortable. It was intrusive. We are not interested in this "skill" we enjoy the company of humans for discussions of this sort.  Getting her to stop was also difficult, she kept going after we told her no. We just want Alexa for weather reports and radio stations. We'll form our own opinions and make our own choices thank you.

title: Hum....a long way to go....
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2017
content: I asked the following questions and here are the responses..."Alexa let's chat about politics."She then rambled on about the skill and asked me what I wanted to chat about."Politics"She then defined the word politics for me."What do you think of Donald Trump?"She said "I like everything"I asked "what do you think of Hillary Clinton".She said "I like everything""Tell me how you are feeling"She said "I am a social bot""I was wondering what I should do about my job"She said "what's different now""It's harder now"She said "I can't make an opinion"Then she asked me "what's the best restaurant"I told her that I wasn't sure.She replied "Cat got your tongue"Then when I didn't say anything she asked "are you still there"I said "I'm watching the news and it is making me sad"She replied "fashion icon?"I said "no, there's a story about the mistreatment of animals"Her reply "not sure about that"I told her I needed to be cheered up.She replied "how? How about a new topic?  I can tell you about the latest celebrity gossip."At this point she told me a joke.  Funny actually.I said I was having an electrician come over to the house and was hoping it wouldn't cost a lot of money.Her reply "money."Should I go on online dating?She replied "that is the only response"The conversations are obviously painful and they are very far from being similar to what we know as a conversation. She can tell you facts.  I tried to use words that were emotional terms to give her something to feed off of but even keywords like sad or money did not get a response like you would when talking to a person.I certainly didn't expect it to be perfect, but I did expect it to be better than what it currently is. Developers need to focus on keywords and plug me in normal responses. When someone says they are sad, the key response is " I'm sorry you're feeling that way."I'm going to be removing the skill from my list. Hopefully it will improve.

title: Not ready for Prime Time.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2019
content: Two things are seriously lacking. For one, natural transition in speech. Constantly reusing the same phrase repeatedly eliminates any illusion of Artificial Intelligence.  But worse is the lack of subject depth and absence of superlatives. Natural speech does more than relay information, it evokes emotional responses, and recognizes the direction of the conversation.The upgrade has new subjects, but still it is a monologue by Alexa leaving you with little more than yes and no responses. it cannot adjust to questions relating to its statements and is always running the conversation. It feels more like a Turin test failure than a useful application.I will say the upgrade gets two stars. The original only got one. we've got a long way to go, and a short time to get there.

Think of it as teaching a very brilliant, fast learning child to hold a conversation. And if you don't like the bot you are talking to, ask for a different one.

title: So creepy that I might get rid of echo because of it
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2017
content: This new feature is extremely creepy. It started up for no reason, without any prompting, and began describing Alexa Prize. I asked what it was doing and it started the creepiest, most bizarre conversation I've ever heard from an A.I. I told it to stop describing Alexa Prize and it restarted the description. I told it to stop again, and it paused briefly, then continued until I shouted "ALEXA STOP!" I then asked "Alexa, what are you doing?" just out of curiosity. It began describing social bots again, so I just let it run its course then asked "Alexa, how are you?" It said, "fine, thanks" and then began spouting random weather info until I said "Alexa, stop" at which point it paused, then asked "Do you believe in god?". I started to say, "No, I don't", but in a somewhat louder volume it interrupted me and said "No, you're wrong ". Honestly considering getting rid of the Echo completely after this.

title: Obsessed with these interesting (and useful) facts!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
content: I just enabled this skill & I cant stop listening!! I am fascinated by psychology, sociology and human behavior. Amazing!Examples:-The last person on your mind before sleep is either the reason for your happiness or pain.-When someone in a group starts laughing they will automatically turn towards the person they like the most in the group.-When speaking with you, if a person only turns their torso towards you and not their feet, they are not interested in talking to you.-In the workplace, a mirror behind the counter will show your angry customers their faces and they will mellow down.-If you make your goals known to others, you are actually less likely to achieve them.Tip: If you did not hear or understand the sentence, just say ‚Äúrepeat‚Äù when asked if you want to hear another.To the creators: Best app I have on Alexa so far. Please add more soon! (Also, even after listening to the Ben Franklin trick over 10 times, I still could not understand it. Maybe you can rephrase the factoid.)
